akiec.name: Actinic Keratoses and Intraepithelial Carcinoma
akiec.description: Actinic keratoses (AK) are precancerous skin lesions caused by long-term sun exposure. They appear as rough, scaly patches on sun-exposed areas. Intraepithelial carcinoma represents early-stage skin cancer that hasn't penetrated deeper layers.
symptoms: Rough, dry, or scaly patch of skin
recommendations: Consult a dermatologist for evaluation and treatment options
Treatment may include cryotherapy, topical medications, or photodynamic therapy
Use broad-spectrum sunscreen (SPF 30+) daily
Wear protective clothing and avoid peak sun hours
Regular skin checks by a dermatologist
akiec.emergency_care: Seek immediate care if the lesion grows rapidly, bleeds persistently, or becomes painful.
akiec.prognosis: Good with treatment. AK has a small chance of progressing to squamous cell carcinoma if left untreated.

bcc.name: Basal Cell Carcinoma
bcc.description: Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is the most common type of skin cancer, originating from basal cells in the skin's outer layer. It rarely spreads but can cause significant local damage if untreated.
risk_factors: Fair skin, light hair, and light eyes
symptoms: Bleeding or scabbing sore that heals and returns
recommendations: Schedule an appointment with a dermatologist promptly
Surgical removal is typically recommended
Regular follow-up examinations are important
Sun protection is essential to prevent new lesions
Avoid tanning beds and excessive sun exposure
bcc.emergency_care: While BCC grows slowly, seek medical attention if you notice rapid changes, excessive bleeding, or signs of infection.
bcc.prognosis: Excellent when detected and treated early. Cure rate exceeds 95% with appropriate treatment.

bkl.name: Benign Keratosis-like Lesions
bkl.description: Benign keratosis-like lesions include seborrheic keratoses and solar lentigo. These are non-cancerous skin growths that are extremely common, especially with aging. They are harmless but may be cosmetically concerning.
symptoms: Looks like it's pasted on the skin
recommendations: No treatment necessary unless cosmetically bothersome
Monitor for any changes in appearance
Regular skin self-examinations
Annual dermatology check-ups
Can be removed for cosmetic reasons
bkl.emergency_care: Seek evaluation if a lesion changes rapidly in size, color, or begins to bleed, as it could indicate a different condition.
bkl.prognosis: Benign with no risk of becoming cancerous. These lesions are harmless and only require treatment if desired for cosmetic reasons.

df.name: Dermatofibroma
df.description: Dermatofibroma is a common benign skin growth composed of fibrous tissue. It typically appears as a small, firm nodule on the legs. The cause is unknown, but may follow minor trauma or insect bites.
risk_factors: Typically appears in young to middle-aged adults
symptoms: Small, firm bump under the skin
May be slightly itchy or tender
recommendations: No treatment required unless symptomatic
Routine monitoring is sufficient
Can be surgically removed if bothersome
Keep the area clean and moisturized
Avoid picking or scratching
df.emergency_care: Generally no emergency care needed. Consult a doctor if the lesion grows rapidly, becomes very painful, or changes significantly.
df.prognosis: Excellent. Dermatofibromas are benign and rarely cause complications. They may remain indefinitely or slowly fade over years.

mel.name: Melanoma
mel.description: Melanoma is the most serious type of skin cancer, developing from melanocytes (pigment-producing cells). It can spread rapidly to other parts of the body if not detected early. Early detection and treatment are critical.
risk_factors: History of sunburns, especially in childhood
Fair skin, light hair, light eyes
symptoms: Evolving (changing in size, shape, or color)
recommendations: URGENT: Consult a dermatologist immediately for evaluation
Biopsy and staging will determine treatment
May require surgical excision with wide margins
Lymph node evaluation may be necessary
Regular full-body skin examinations
Genetic counseling if family history present
mel.emergency_care: Seek immediate medical attention. Early diagnosis dramatically improves survival rates. Do not delay consultation with a dermatologist or oncologist.
mel.prognosis: Highly dependent on stage at diagnosis. Early-stage melanoma has excellent cure rates (>95%). Advanced melanoma requires aggressive treatment and has poorer outcomes.

nv.name: Melanocytic Nevi (Moles)
nv.description: Melanocytic nevi, commonly known as moles, are benign growths of melanocytes. Most people have 10-40 moles. While generally harmless, they should be monitored for changes that might indicate melanoma.
symptoms: Even color (brown, tan, black, or pink)
recommendations: Routine monitoring for changes (ABCDE rule)
Annual skin examination by dermatologist
Monthly self-skin examinations
Sun protection to prevent new moles
Photograph suspicious moles to track changes
Consider removal if atypical features present
nv.emergency_care: Seek evaluation if a mole shows signs of melanoma (asymmetry, irregular borders, color changes, diameter >6mm, or evolution/changes).
nv.prognosis: Excellent. Most moles remain benign throughout life. Regular monitoring ensures early detection if changes occur.
treatment_options: Surgical excision (if atypical or cosmetic concerns)

vasc.name: Vascular Lesions
vasc.description: Vascular lesions are abnormalities of blood vessels in the skin. They include hemangiomas, angiomas, and telangiectasias. Most are benign and cosmetic, though some may require treatment.
risk_factors: Age (cherry angiomas more common with aging)
recommendations: Medical evaluation to determine specific type
Most require no treatment
Treatment available for cosmetic concerns
Monitor for changes or bleeding
Protect from trauma
Sun protection recommended
vasc.emergency_care: Seek medical care if a vascular lesion bleeds persistently, grows rapidly, or causes pain. Most vascular lesions are not urgent.
vasc.prognosis: Excellent. Most vascular lesions are benign and stable. Some may fade over time, especially in children.
